idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3000

descript.abstract: Dataset clipped to Primary/Secondary Delta (David Ford Consulting Engineers, 2013)The Pipeline Safety Act of 1981 created the State Fire Marshal's Pipeline Safety Program. The Pipeline Safety Program has jurisdiction and regulatory responsibility over the safety of interstate hazardous liquid pipelines in California and is located within the Hazardous Materials Division. In a broad-brush definition, these are lines that carry crude oil from production facilities (or terminals) to refineries and lines that carry refined products from the refineries to storage facilities or across the state line. The Pipeline Safety Program also maintains Interstate Agent status through the Federal Office of Pipeline Safety for similar jurisdiction over interstate hazardous liquid pipelines. In 1995, Assembly Member Kuehl introduced AB 592, which was later signed by Gov. Pete Wilson and codified as Sections 51017 to 51017.2 of the California Government Code. The law requires the State Fire Marshal to create a comprehensive Geographic Information System (GIS) database of pipeline information for the specific intent of emergency response. It requires the State Fire Marshal to notify the pipeline operators if a pipeline is within 1000 feet of a public drinking water well. Those pipeline operators must then develop and submit a wellhead protection plan to the State Fire Marshal for approval. This GIS data set is intended for internal use in the California State Fire Marshal, as base data for field operations. It is also intended for use in the Office of Emergency Services incident command and local emergency response efforts. We intend this GIS data set to be used as spatial reference by other State, Federal and local agencies for analysis mandated by the State of California legislature.
descript.purpose: Oil Pipeline locations in CA Delta
descript.supplinf:
File Source: Oil & Gas (Petroleum) Pipelines - crude and product
File Obtained: March 2005
Obtained from: Lisa Dowdy Fire Marshal - Pipeline Safety Division Dept. of Forestry and Fire Protection 916-445-8363 lisa.dowdy@fire.ca.gov
doug.allen@fire.ca.gov
(Note: a good CEC source for information: Michael Nyberg, TED Office - 916-654-5968)
Contact Letter:
Lisa Dowdy, I work at the California Energy Commission in the GIS/Cartography Unit. I received from Doug Allen, about 2 years ago (10/2/02), GIS data for petroleum pipelines (crude and product) for the entire state. I have heard a recent update of this information has been completed. I would like to obtain the new data to use with other GIS layers we have, such as transmission lines and power plants. The Commission datasets are used for energy research and evaluation by Commission staff for projects such as: power plant siting case studies, transmission corridor critical path studies, and natural gas and petroleum studies of energy coming into California from other states and from Mexico. Currently, I'm working on a request to show what species diversity is found in selected petroleum pipelines for a biology study being done by a Commission planner. We understand that the dataset you provide is sensitive information and we intend to use this information for inclusion in projects for internal review.
Since this data is critical for current projects, I would like to request a rush on receiving this from you, if at all possible. I appreciate your consideration in this matter, and I would be happy to answer any further questions you may have regarding our use of this dataset.
If this information is being sent on a CD, please send to the following address: California Energy Commission 1516 9th Street MS 49 Sacramento, California 95814 Attention: Jacque Gilbreath - Cartography
Regards, Jacque Gilbreath
Hi Terry, Yes, the 99 series of numbers means it's an unknown diameter. -----Original Message----- From: TERRY ROSE [mailto:TROSE@energy.state.ca.us] Sent: Monday, April 11, 2005 3:57 PM To: Dowdy, Lisa Subject: Oil & Gas (Petroleum) Pipelines * crude and product Lisa We have a .shp file showing the Oil & Gas (Petroleum) Pipelines in CA that we received from your agency. In the attribute table there is a field that list the diameter which ranges from 2 inches to 42 inches then it jumps to sizes like 99.9999 or 99999.9999 this can't be diameter. Would this be unknown dia?? I have attached the metadata that was included with the file and don't see a definition for those numbers. Do you know what they mean? Thanks

dataIdInfo.idAbs:
Dataset clipped to Primary/Secondary Delta (David Ford Consulting Engineers, 2013)

The Pipeline Safety Act of 1981 created the State Fire Marshal's Pipeline Safety Program. The Pipeline Safety Program has jurisdiction and regulatory responsibility over the safety of interstate hazardous liquid pipelines in California and is located within the Hazardous Materials Division. In a broad-brush definition, these are lines that carry crude oil from production facilities (or terminals) to refineries and lines that carry refined products from the refineries to storage facilities or across the state line. The Pipeline Safety Program also maintains Interstate Agent status through the Federal Office of Pipeline Safety for similar jurisdiction over interstate hazardous liquid pipelines. In 1995, Assembly Member Kuehl introduced AB 592, which was later signed by Gov. Pete Wilson and codified as Sections 51017 to 51017.2 of the California Government Code. The law requires the State Fire Marshal to create a comprehensive Geographic Information System (GIS) database of pipeline information for the specific intent of emergency response. It requires the State Fire Marshal to notify the pipeline operators if a pipeline is within 1000 feet of a public drinking water well. Those pipeline operators must then develop and submit a wellhead protection plan to the State Fire Marshal for approval. This GIS data set is intended for internal use in the California State Fire Marshal, as base data for field operations. It is also intended for use in the Office of Emergency Services incident command and local emergency response efforts. We intend this GIS data set to be used as spatial reference by other State, Federal and local agencies for analysis mandated by the State of California legislature.

Consts.useLimit: BY ACCEPTING THIS FILE YOU AGREE TO THE FOLLOWING STATEMENT: I understand that any and all data/information obtained from the Office of the State Fire Marshal's Pipeline mapping System is sensitive security information and I agree to: restrict disclosure of and access to this data/information to persons with official state and local government responsibility; to not redistribute the data/information; and to refer requests by other persons for such information to the Mapping Coordinator for OSFM. I also agree to maintain a list of those persons that have been provided access to this information.

LegConsts.othConsts:
Due to recent events the California State Fire Marshal (CSFM) is currently following the lead of the U.S. Department of Transportation's Office of Pipeline Safety when disseminating pipeline GIS data. At this time, CSFM is only providing pipeline GIS data to pipeline operators and local, State and Federal government offices.
Operators will only be provided the data they have submitted to the State Pipeline Mapping System. Pipeline operators requesting their pipeline data should send an email to spms@fire.ca.gov. Include your name, title, company, mailing address, phone number, fax number, email address and CSFM inspection unit.
Local, State and Federal government officials requesting pipeline data should send an email to spms@fire.ca.gov. Include your name, title, organization, mailing address, fax number, email address, geographic location your interested in and a description of data use.

dataIdInfo.idPurp: Oil Pipeline locations in CA Delta
dataIdInfo.idCredit: California Energy Comission, via David Ford Consulting Engineers, 2013.

procstep.srcused: C:\Documents and Settings\Ldowdy\My Documents\Plains Pipeline, L.P..shp.xml

dataLineage.statement:
Pipeline operators submitting pipeline data for inclusion into the State Pipeline Mapping System must follow predefined submission standards. Data was submitted in digital or paper format to the California State Fire Marshal following these standards. The standards may be viewed at the State Fire Marshal website (http://osfm.fire.ca.gov).
Data was also delivered to the California State Fire Marshal as Mylar overlay. Overlays were typically 1:28000 scale. Overlays were located with suitable reference coordinates and digitized using Arc/Info rev 8x software. In some cases, where reference control was sparse, a transformation process was used to transform coordinates in inch space to real world space. The transformation process used the best possible 4 control points from groups of at least 20 control points. No transformation greater than .004 RMS, 1 rotation and .1 skew was used. Multiple map pages were hand edge matched using Teal scanned USGS 7.5 minute quadrangles as back coverage's. Edge matching was performed on 100% of the data. Individual pipeline segments were joined, attributed and appended to a master set.
Paper maps, with USGS scanned quadrangles as back coverage, were supplied back to the individual operators as a quality control measure.
